awd_titl_txt: RAPID/Collaborative Research: The 2022 Yellowstone Flood: Evaluating National Parks as Critical Infrastructures to the US Ecotourism Economy
awd_abstract_narration:
Yellowstone National Park (YNP) sustains over 4 million visitors annually and generates over 8,700 jobs and greater than $830 million of benefits to the surrounding region’s economy. During June 2022, a 500-yr flood event swept across YNP and gateway communities destroying road and building infrastructures, leading to the closure of the park and the evacuation of more than 10,000 visitors. YNP remained fully closed for 9 days and subsequently reopened partially under variable entry systems; however, the northern entrances have remained closed, disconnecting gateway communities and crippling dependent economies. The economic impacts from the YNP closures on the region’s eco-tourism industry is expected to be severe in the following years. The Yellowstone flood experience runs counter to conventional disaster risk paradigms, which focus on the exposure, vulnerability, and resilience of the ‘built-up environment’, such as risks to human health, property damages, or critical infrastructures. In contrast, the Yellowstone flooding suggests that an extreme disturbance in a national park, or natural infrastructure, can induce severe and systemic economic impacts to entire regions. This suggests that natural infrastructures can operate similarly to human-built infrastructures in providing critical services for human livelihoods. Ultimately, this brings into question how society should manage and value protected land assets and extends society’s valuation of US National Parks, “America’s Best Idea”, beyond mere aesthetics to an accurate portrayal of serving critical roles in preserving our nation’s economic and public health security and safety. This Rapid Response Research (RAPID) project seeks to monitor and understand the infrastructural and economic impacts and recovery, as they rapidly unfold over the next weeks and months to understand the interdependencies between humans and natural infrastructures, particularly exposing society’s vulnerability to disasters in non-built-up areas. 

The objective of the work is to rapidly collect ephemeral information critical to documenting and understanding the infrastructural impacts of the YNP flooding, the rate and nature of infrastructure evolution and recovery, and the systemic economic impacts of the flooding on the ecotourism-dependent industries in the gateway communities. Comprehensive inventories of infrastructure loss, damage, and recovery will occur via direct observation and photo documentation. Through interviews and web surveillance, the impacts of the closures and re-openings on economics, regional travel, and human activities will be documented. Finally, the FEWSION for Community Resilience (F4R™) program will identify social and physical infrastructures embedded within the region’s critical supply chains and provide communities with approaches to mitigate future disaster risks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Yellowstone National Park (YNP) sustains over 4 million visitors annually and generates 8,736 jobs and $834 million of benefits to the surrounding region’s economy. During June 2022, a 500-yr flood event swept across Yellowstone National Park (YNP) and gateway communities destroying road and building infrastructures, leading to the closure of the park and the evacuation of more than 10,000 visitors.  Although the park eventually reached 100% operating capacity by late fall 2022, the economic impacts from the YNP closures on the region’s eco-tourism industry were severe.

This project documented the critical importance of YNP to regional economies by evaluating the economic and infrastructural recovery of the park and gateway communities following the flood.  Through two major field campaigns and remote web surveillance, our team rapidly collected ephemeral information critical to documenting and understanding the infrastructural impacts of the YNP flooding, the rate and nature of infrastructure evolution and recovery, and the systemic economic impacts of the flooding on the ecotourism-dependent industries in the gateway communities. The team conducted an economic survey of impacts by visiting over 200 businesses within five gateway communities during September 2022. Monitoring traffic volume responses has been ongoing since the flood and included the collection of at least 10 million images from web-cameras from five gateway areas. Comprehensive inventories of infrastructure loss, damage, and recovery occurred via direct observation and photo documentation. The team visited YNP almost one year following the flood and re-inventoried 90% of YNP flood-impacted infrastructures previously documented by the National Park Service. A FEWSION for Community Resilience (F4R™) workshop was used to identify social and physical infrastructures imbedded within the region’s critical supply chains and provide communities with approaches to mitigate future disaster risks.

The economic survey conducted directly following the flood in September 2022 showed that the effects of the YNP Park closures were severe to the Gardiner and Cooke City, Montana communities, where businesses lost, on average, 75% of their summer season income, the predominant source of annual income for the year.  Our economic model suggested the flood led to a total loss of $156 million in visitor spending in gateway areas in 2022, exceeding economic losses from the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020. This suggests that the 2022 Yellowstone Flood has severe and long-lasting impacts on these communities. The results of the surveys were provided to the U.S. Economic Development Agency for use in their reporting summaries to determine the level of support needed.  The F4R community resilience workshop led to critical thought on how to build resilience for Southwest Montana and connections to the park, particularly engaging community leaders in alternative infrastructure needs and economic rebuilding for the future.  A meta-analysis on traffic studies in national parks revealed important research gaps in the literature important to inform future transportation sustainability – particularly linkages and inter-dependencies between traffic in gateways and within the park.  The 2023 trip to re-inventory flood-damages within YNP found that the majority of road and lodging infrastructures have been repaired within one year following the flood; however, most trails and natural infrastructures have not been repaired and, as of August 2023, were still in states of disrepair.

Currently, the project has provided opportunities for engaging seven PhD graduate students, all of whom will or have traveled to Yellowstone associated with the project, five of which will have their first experience visiting the nation’s oldest National Park. The project supported one female Co-PI, three female PhD students, one of whom was supported by the National Science Foundation under an internship at Oak Ridge National Laboratory, and three underrepresented undergraduate students. At least seven graduate students, four females, had direct immersive field research experiences in YNP.  Products of the research currently include two journal articles undergoing revision, multiple articles in prep, three news pieces, a podcast, and a website dedicated to disseminating research.

The Yellowstone flood experience runs counter to conventional disaster risk paradigms, which focus on the exposure, vulnerability, and resilience of the ‘built-up environment’, such as risks to human health, property damages, or critical infrastructures. In contrast, the Yellowstone flooding suggests that an extreme disturbance in a national park, or natural infrastructure, can induce severe and systemic economic impacts to entire regions. Ultimately, this questions how society should manage and value protected land assets and extends society’s valuation of US National Parks, i.e., America’s Best Idea, beyond mere aesthetics to an accurate portrayal of serving critical roles in preserving our nation’s economic and public health security and safety.
